message: opinions?
love the idea, but it takes some getting used to. might have a look at rmail too, though people seem to prefer GNUs these days.

I love emacs, it's the best programmers editor I've ever found for all python, erlang, make, misc config files, HTML, js, etc.  But I've never understood the desire to live inside it.  It's a poor enough editor that I can't imagine it also being a very good mail client/news reader.  I've tried at some point, but shoddy/non-existant IMAP support was a non-starter.
All things will be better in the future.
Gnus has imap support.
I'm not sure of its quality though.
The one ding I've heard against it is that it blocks the interface when fetching, but, afaik, the concurrency branch in emacs24 should fix that.

I have used gnus for more than a decade. Besides its great support for all of the same keystrokes that I originally learned so that I could read news in the late 1980s using "rn", the real win for me is how often I have to jump back and forth between documents and other emails when composing new emails. The ability of Emacs to jump quickly between buffers and files is crucial to my ability to quickly reference, say, three other messages and a document to put together an answer. Or a question!

Can anyone show their workflow for using it? I've been very curious about using gnus for quite sometime and have made attempts to use it but don't quite fully understand how to use it as a decent mail client.
Yea I've tried to use GNUS with gmail before but I personally didn't care for it. I
I use gnus for mail (local IMAP) and news.  I have a elscreen-tab reserved for it.
Also use gnus for mailing. I tried so many other mail clients before, but something always pissed me of. With gnus (local imap) i can program my mailer easy now to fit my needs.
I use Emacs for everything that has to do with text editing: Programming, emails, newsgroups, notes.

I configured Gnus in 2003 and haven't touch the configuration since.  At least not significantly.  Statements like "Client XY is the best in the world" are pointless of course, but anyway Gnus is good enough so that I don't have to learn the editor of another email client.  The only disadvantage is that the set of maintainers seems to be quite small.
gnus' IMAP support was rewritten late last year. I used it exclusively from the mid 90's until about 2003 when I changed to a Mac. These days I use it for following gmane groups, mostly.
@justinlilly I use Gnus with Gmail's POP/IMAP/SMTP just fine.
I've yet to get gnus working properly. Need to give a good weekend to it.
